cards.front: What is approximation in computational methods?
cards.back: Replacing complex, intractable quantities with simpler, tractable ones. Example: linearizing the diode equation around a bias point.
Converting continuous-domain problems into discrete-point problems for digital processing. Example: sampling x(t) at intervals Ts to get x[n] = x(nTs).
To avoid aliasing, the sampling frequency must be at least twice the highest frequency component: fs ≥ 2·fmax.
When a signal is sampled below the Nyquist rate, high-frequency components fold back and appear as false lower frequencies. This is irreversible.

cards.front: What does transformation mean in computational methods?
cards.back: Mapping a problem into a different domain where it becomes simpler. Example: Laplace transform converts differential equations into algebraic equations.

cards.front: How does the Laplace transform simplify differential equations?
cards.back: It converts differentiation to multiplication by s and integration to division by s, turning differential equations into algebraic equations.
Approximating a nonlinear system with a linear one around an operating point using the Jacobian: ẋ̃ ≈ Aẋ̃ + Bũ, where A = ∂f/∂x and B = ∂f/∂u.

cards.front: What is the key limitation of linearization?
cards.back: It is only valid for small perturbations around the operating point. Large deviations cause the linear model to diverge from reality.
A dimension reduction technique that finds orthogonal directions of maximum variance, allowing high-dimensional data to be represented with fewer coefficients: x ≈ x̄ + Σ ak·vk.

cards.front: What common trade-off do all five foundational principles share?
cards.back: They all trade some form of accuracy or information for tractability. Approximation loses exactness, discretization loses resolution, transformation may lose intuition, linearization loses range, dimension reduction loses minor variation.

cards.front: Give an ECE example that combines multiple foundational principles.
cards.back: SPICE simulation uses discretization (time stepping), approximation (device model simplification), linearization (Newton-Raphson for nonlinear equations), and transformation (frequency-domain AC analysis).
